_header: Listeneth now and ye shall hear / Talking of a good matere
Note: For other MSS without a prologue see 3245; for others with a 32-line prologue, see 3748.
Bibliographic Ghosts: Oxford, Bodleian Library Digby 88 (SC 1689), ff. 75-76v: see 3124; London, British Library Harley 1735, (a) f. 13v and (b) ff. 14v-16v: 3124; Oxford, Bodleian Library Ashmole 189 (SC 6777), f. 210: see 3245; London, Wellcome Historical Medical Library 411, f. 1: see 3245.
_description: Prognostics from the day on which Christmas falls, with a 16-line prologue — in couplets

CamTCC600.First Lines:
But yit takeþe heede andyee shall hereA tale nye acordant to
                    þis mater…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…He gyve vs grace oure destenye beTo seo him in heven in his
                    see
CamTCC600.Note:
126 lines; follow immediately 1593 as if part of same text, but RT changes (pp.
                    256-7) to ‘A dyetarie for mans gouernaunce’.

BLSl1315.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “English Almanacks of the XVth Century.” 
             Philological Quarterly
         18 (1939): 321-31: 330 (extracts).

HunHM64.First Lines:
LIstenythe nowe & ye schall hyreTalkynge of a goode
                    matere…
HunHM64.Last Lines:
…Grawnt vs all thy dire blessyngeThat we maye com to thy
                    blysse euerlastynge
